data.title: Sampler states of DirectX effects are applied in the wrong order
data.body:
Problem:
Here is an example effect with two textures and two different sampler states:
https://gist.github.com/DigitalRune/5037370

Texture A should use sampler state A, and texture B should use sampler state B. But when the effect is used, texture A is sampled with sampler state B and vice versa.

Cause:
MonoGame assumes that textures and samplers are always bound to the same slot at the pixel shader state. But in this example this is not the case. When I debug 2MGFX and check the shader reflection info, I can see that texture A is bound at slot 1 and sampler A is bound at slot 0. 
My interpretation is: Textures are assigned to texture slots in the order in which they are used (i.e. the order of the tex2d() calls). Sampler states are assigned to slots in the order in which they are defined.

Solution:
In 2MGFX, store the textureSlot and samplerSlot with the sampler info - not only a single index for both. - I have made some quick tests and this should solve the problem. Should I prepare a pull request?

Workaround:
In the effect file, always define the textures+samplers in the order in which they are used.

data.title: Numbers in generated GLSL are invalid on PCs with non-English culture
data.body:
Problem:
I build a simple shader using the MGEffectProcessor. At runtime the generated GLSL cannot be compiled because it contains invalid constants like these:

```
const vec4 vs_c0 = vec4(-1,000000.0, 1,000000.0, 0,000000.0, 0,000000.0);
const vec4 vs_cl = vec4(0,002500.0, -0,004167.0. l,00000.0, 0,000000.0);
```

Cause:
My PC uses English as the UI language but German for the number formatting. I guess this causes mojoshader to produce invalid numbers???

Workaround:
In the control panel of your PC set the culture for formats to English(United States). Restart VisualStudio and try again. Then following correct GLSL is produced.

```
const vec4 vs_c0 = vec4(-1.0. 1.0, 0.0, 0.0);
const vec4 vs_c1 = vec4(0.0025, -0.004167, 1.0, 0.0);
```

More information:
The problem only occurs when shaders are generated in the content pipeline. If I debug 2MGFX.exe, the problem is not there.

data.body:
When the SetData() method of a texture is called, the caller must provide a valid target region and data with the correct number of bytes. A data array which is too small could cause UpdateSubresource() to read data outside the valid bounds.
The SetData() method should check if the number of bytes is correct for the given surface format and target region. If an incorrect number of bytes is specified, an ArgumentException should be thrown. XNA throws: "The size of the data passed in is too large or too small for this resource."

data.title: [WinDX] Cannot change IsMouseVisible at runtime.
data.body:
On Windows/DirectX, changing IsMouseVisible at runtime has no effect. In our application, we can dynamically show/hide a GUI and therefore we also want to change IsMouseVisible at runtime.

As far as I can see, the problem is that WindowsGamePlatform.OnIsMouseVisibleChanged was removed in this commit: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/f5c3a68f36f1246d6a53b91df4d7885e806dd678

Further, this commit https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/ee60155053cd3fdec20a5ac9f2f057c37b2548f6 added code to show/hide the cursor when the it leaves the window. In my experience, this is the Windows default behavior, so the code is unnecessary.

@xanather 
Could you please comment why this WindowsGamePlatform.OnIsMouseVisibleChanged() was removed?
Could you please comment why showing/hiding the cursor in MouseEnter/MouseLeave is necessary?

Proposed solution:
I get the same cursor behavior as in XNA when I do the following:
In the WindowsGamePlatform constructor call Cursor.Hide (because IsMouseVisible defaults to false). 
In WindowsGamePlatform.OnIsMouseVisibleChanged call Cursor.Show/Hide as needed. Do nothing in WinFormsGameWindow.MouseEnter/MouseLeave.

data.title: Fix: Mipmap levels of DXT textures were not loaded correctly in DirectX
data.body:
This patch fixes following bug:
In DirectX, mipmap levels of DXTCompressed textures where the width/height is not a multiple of 4 where not loaded correctly. The width/height of each level must be a multiple of 4 because this is the DXT block size. For example, the last mipmap level which is usually 1x1 texels must be treated as 4x4 texels in UpdateSubresource().

This patch fixes the following issue: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1415

The OpenGL implementation is unchanged and works. (GL.CompressedTexImage2D() works if we treat the last level as 1x1. It does not work if we treat the last level as 4x4.)

data.title: Unable to use/force OpenGL 1.1 (for performance reasons)
data.body:
This issue was found using the iOS project, but may apply to other platforms as well. When forcing OpenGL 1.1 in iOSGameView.cs->CreateContext, a MonoGameGLException is thrown in GraphicsExtensions.cs->CheckGLError, with an "Invalid Operation" (All.InvalidOperation) error. (see entire stack trace below). I haven't dug into why this is happening because I don't know that much about OpenGL yet.

OpenGL 1.1 performs much better on older devices for the 2D game I am working on, and the OpenGL 2.0 path seems that it would only be usable if I were to try and eliminate almost all overdrawing.

Here are the FPS rates that I see with 1.1 vs. 2.0, when drawing the same texture "n" times, with a destination rectangle equal to the resolution of the device's screen (in this test case, the destination rectangle was 960x640 on the iPhone 4 - source texture size didn't matter):

Open GL 1.1:

MG 3.0
- unable to use OpenGL 1.1

MG 2.x
- 1-4 draws: 60fps
- 5 draws: 55fps
- 10 draws: 30fps

Open GL 2.0:

All MG versions (MG 2.0, 2.5, 3.0) are the same:
- 1 draw: 59-60fps
- 1.5 draws: 42fps (one destination of 960x640, another destination of 480x640)
- 2 draws: 32fps
- 3 draws: 22fps
- 4 draws: 16fps
- 5 draws: 13fps
- 10 draws: 7fps

In the game I am working on, I draw a background image with a destination of 960x640, then other images on top, and because of the extra overdrawing, the frame rate drops dramatically. When using MG 2.x, and forcing OpenGL 1.1, I maintain 60fps.

I would like to use MG 3, and force OpenGL 1.1 on older hardware.
